pages.raw_output:
<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 194, 220, 208]]<|/det|>
# MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 216, 304, 232]]<|/det|>
Paper 5 Mechanics 2 (M2)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 259, 460, 303]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Answer Booklet/Paper Graph Paper List of Formulae (MF9)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 320, 390, 337]]<|/det|>
READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 352, 828, 368]]<|/det|>
If you have been given an Answer Booklet, follow the instructions on the front cover of the Booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 368, 722, 384]]<|/det|>
Write your Centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 384, 325, 400]]<|/det|>
Write in dark blue or black pen.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 400, 495, 416]]<|/det|>
You may use a soft pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 416, 601, 432]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, highlighters, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 447, 285, 463]]<|/det|>
Answer all the questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 463, 907, 494]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place in the case of angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 494, 720, 510]]<|/det|>
Where a numerical value for the acceleration due to gravity is needed, use \(10 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) .  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 510, 590, 526]]<|/det|>
The use of an electronic calculator is expected, where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 526, 606, 543]]<|/det|>
You are reminded of the need for clear presentation in your answers.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 557, 606, 573]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 573, 757, 589]]<|/det|>
The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 590, 440, 605]]<|/det|>
The total number of marks for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 605, 907, 636]]<|/det|>
Questions carrying smaller numbers of marks are printed earlier in the paper, and questions carrying larger numbers of marks later in the paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.6 \mathrm{kg}\) is projected horizontally with velocity \(2 \mathrm{m s}^{-1}\) from a point \(O\) on a smooth horizontal surface. A horizontal force of magnitude \(0.3x \mathrm{N}\) acts on \(P\) in the direction \(OP\), where \(x \mathrm{m}\) is the distance of \(P\) from \(O\). Calculate the velocity of \(P\) when \(x = 8\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 106, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 152, 94, 170]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 151, 920, 185]]<|/det|>
A uniform hemispherical shell of weight \(8 \mathrm{N}\) and a uniform solid hemisphere of weight \(12 \mathrm{N}\) are joined along their circumferences to form a non-uniform sphere of radius \(0.2 \mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 198, 156, 216]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 198, 920, 231]]<|/det|>
Show that the distance between the centre of mass of the sphere and the centre of the sphere is \(0.005 \mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 214, 920, 231]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 244, 920, 293]]<|/det|>
This sphere is placed on a horizontal surface with its axis of symmetry horizontal. The equilibrium of the sphere is maintained by a force of magnitude \(F \mathrm{N}\) acting parallel to the axis of symmetry applied to the highest point of the sphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 307, 151, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 306, 260, 324]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(F\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 307, 920, 324]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 352, 94, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 352, 920, 416]]<|/det|>
A light elastic string has natural length \(2.2 \mathrm{m}\) and modulus of elasticity \(14.3 \mathrm{N}\). A particle \(P\) of mass \(m \mathrm{kg}\) is attached to the mid-point of the string. The ends of the string are attached to fixed points \(A\) and \(B\) which are \(2.4 \mathrm{m}\) apart at the same horizontal level. \(P\) is released from rest at the mid-point of \(AB\). In the subsequent motion \(P\) has its greatest speed at a point \(0.5 \mathrm{m}\) below \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 432, 148, 448]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 432, 223, 448]]<|/det|>
Find \(m\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 432, 920, 448]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 462, 151, 479]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 462, 428, 479]]<|/det|>
Calculate the greatest speed of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 462, 920, 479]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 508, 94, 526]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 508, 920, 540]]<|/det|>
A particle \(P\) of mass \(0.25 \mathrm{kg}\) moves in a straight line on a smooth horizontal surface. At time \(t\) s the velocity of \(P\) is \(\nu \mathrm{m} \mathrm{s}^{- 1}\). A variable force of magnitude \(3t \mathrm{N}\) opposes the motion of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 555, 146, 572]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 555, 613, 572]]<|/det|>
Given that \(P\) comes to rest when \(t = 3\), find \(\nu\) when \(t = 0\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 555, 920, 572]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 586, 151, 603]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 585, 645, 603]]<|/det|>
Calculate the distance travelled by \(P\) in the interval \(0 \leqslant t \leqslant 3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 586, 920, 603]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 632, 94, 650]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 631, 920, 681]]<|/det|>
A ball is projected with velocity \(25 \mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) at an angle of \(70^{\circ}\) above the horizontal from a point \(O\) on horizontal ground. The ball subsequently bounces once on the ground at a point \(P\) before landing at a point \(Q\) where it remains at rest. The distance \(PQ\) is \(17.1 \mathrm{m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 695, 151, 712]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 694, 784, 712]]<|/det|>
Calculate the time taken by the ball to travel from \(O\) to \(P\) and the distance \(OP\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 695, 920, 712]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 725, 153, 743]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 725, 920, 758]]<|/det|>
Given that the horizontal component of the velocity of the ball does not change at \(P\), calculate the speed of the ball when it leaves \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 742, 920, 759]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[324, 82, 710, 242]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 259, 920, 294]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a uniform lamina \(ABCDEF\), formed from a semicircle with centre \(O\) and radius \(1 \text{ m}\) by removing a semicircular part with centre \(O\) and radius \(r \text{ m}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 306, 154, 324]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 306, 781, 324]]<|/det|>
Show that the distance in metres of the centre of mass of the lamina from \(O\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[443, 330, 556, 365]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{4(1 + r + r^2)}{3\pi(1 + r)}.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 341, 917, 359]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 384, 548, 402]]<|/det|>
The centre of mass of the lamina lies on the arc \(ABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 415, 153, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[160, 415, 574, 433]]<|/det|>
Show that \(r = 0.494\), correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 415, 920, 433]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 446, 615, 465]]<|/det|>
The lamina is freely suspended at \(F\) and hangs in equilibrium.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 477, 151, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 477, 692, 495]]<|/det|>
Find the angle between the diameter of the lamina and the vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 477, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 523, 92, 542]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 523, 920, 588]]<|/det|>
Particles \(P\) and \(Q\), of masses \(0.8 \mathrm{~kg}\) and \(0.5 \mathrm{~kg}\) respectively, are attached to the ends of a light inextensible string which passes through a small hole in a smooth horizontal table of negligible thickness. \(P\) moves with constant angular speed \(6.25 \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\) in a circular path on the surface of the table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 602, 151, 620]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 602, 920, 635]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(Q\) is stationary and that the part of string attached to \(Q\) is vertical. Calculate the radius of the path of \(P\), and find the speed of \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 648, 153, 666]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 648, 920, 696]]<|/det|>
It is given instead that the part of string attached to \(Q\) is inclined at \(60^{\circ}\) to the vertical, and that \(Q\) moves in a horizontal circular path below the table, also with constant angular speed \(6.25 \mathrm{rad} \mathrm{s}^{-1}\). Calculate the total length of the string.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 680, 920, 698]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]
